pros: I worked at Learning People for nearly a year and thoroughly enjoyed my experience here. I managed to secure this job through the pandemic where I had just recently been made redundant. They haven't made anyone furlough, anyone redundant- they have just hired all the way through. The earning potential is amazing in regards to commission and where it is so fast paced you are able to earn that straight away and to be able to earn a lot during a pandemic is unheard of so I thank Learning People for that. The training was so thorough and helpful and there are always chances for more progression and development if you ever need it. Every member of staff is always happy to help and offer advice, even higher up which never usually happens. review_title: Great opportunity within a growing business
pros:
The induction into the role was the greatest I have witnessed in my entire career history, they provide two weeks of training to ensure that you are fully prepared and an expert in your chosen field prior to speaking to their students. I felt comfortable with the process and encouraged to be the best I could be from the get-go. 

I have to take a moment to sing the praises of Luke, the HR and Recruitment Manager, who genuinely cares about all the staff at the Learning People, and goes out of his way to check in to ensure that you continue to enjoy your role. He encourages an open door policy, and any feedback is valued. 

I also have to say that working with Ali, the Head of Enrollments was an absolute pleasure, he really cares about his staff and the growth of the business and again encourages people to come with new ideas, regardless of how long they have been in the business.

The earning potential is great here, you can really work hard and see the rewards.

Everyone in management, including the CEO has been nothing but welcoming and encouraging, it really is a refreshingly positive place to work.
cons: As it is a growing business there are some staff who are still in a "small-business" mentality and could do with incorporating more professionalism in their day to day, I think in some instances a reset may be needed to align everyone on the businesses core goals as it looks to expand in the coming weeks and months.

Management have got a bit of an clique atmosphere which can be intimidating to approach.

They also paint a really lovely picture when you join about how no one ever leaves and everyone loves working there. That isn't true, it's a revolving door of career consultants. The reason they're always advertising jobs isn't because they're growing, it's because they're replacing people constantly.

pros:
I have worked at the Learning People for several years and I have enjoyed it immensely. We focuses on academic achievement for students and it is hugely rewarding when one of mine succeeds.  

My job is to consult with people who are seeking a new career in IT or already work in the industry, and offer advice on the next steps. I do my best to find a suitable course in our prospectus based on their circumstances. If perhaps a course isn't suitable then I will offer some general advice. 

But beyond that, the company has been very supportive for me in and out of work. They have been flexible regarding working hours and have provided training whenever I needed it. They have in many instances put my family's needs first.
 
I have always found that if an employee believes in the ethos of the company, works hard and has a good attitude, you are given every opportunity to succeed.
cons: The role of Careers Consultant is not for everyone. You can't follow a script. You need to understand the individual's needs and act accordingly. Otherwise people who would- and should- enrol, do not. You cannot use key phrases or 'sales' tricks. I think that if this job is a poor fit for you then it can be very stressful when you don't see success despite hard work.

Working at this company I have found that they lure you in with three main lies...

9-5:30 - This may be true at the beginning but after a while they expect you to work overtime Mon-Fri and Saturdays for no extra pay! No work life balance at all!

review_title: Don't believe the lies. This place is an exceptional place to work.
job_title: SENIOR CAREER CONSULTANT in Hove, England
pros:
I've worked at The Learning People for over 5 years. Before this and the previous job I held, I've had every bad job under the sun for every bad company that don't know how to treat their employees with dignity and respect. 

Reading some of the reviews recently by disgruntled ex and current staff, it's very upsetting to have this company questioned in this way. I haven't had that Sunday night dread once in the entire time I've worked here. Even on its worst day, it's a million times better than anywhere else I've worked. 

People complaining about having to work weekends. Nobody has to work weekends, nobody. But it IS essentially, for some, a Sales Job and if you're struggling to hit your target, it's in your interest to put in more hours. We've all done it, I've done it, it's how you get good at something, then you don't have to do it as much, pretty simple

Along with being left alone to run your own business, weekly massages, beer fridge, company events and nights out, regularly breakfasts, lunches, meals bought for us, Amazon Vouchers and most importantly, a relaxed environment where everybody keeps everybody in check. It's not hard to quickly be reminded of the exceptionally likable atmosphere we've all contributed to over the years

The fact that since I've been here, over 5 years plus, multiple staff who have left have almost instantly regretted it and tried to come back, many successfully, because you'd be pressed to find a better place to work in Brighton / Hove 

I think some people haven't got a clue about how lucky they are to work in such an unbelievably supportive and relaxed environment. The Director very much cares about people and that can be seen both indirectly and directly on regularly occasion. 

If anything, the company has been extremely lenient with people and almost give them too much of a chance to prove themselves. It's a sales role, it is competitive, but it's also consultative and the company is making huge changes to make this an even better place, not just for our staff, but for the students we enrol
cons:
Of course this company isn't perfect, but some of these reviews are so nakedly transparent, they absolutely reek of bitterness. Rather than hold themselves accountable for not being able to do the job and learn what's needed, they simply blame the company.  We've had multiple new people come in to the company in the last 6 months and absolutely smash it out of the park, so what's different about them? Why are they able to do it? Possibly attitude? Possibly perspective, patience and willing to learn? 

Sales isn't for everybody and this company gives people more than a fair chance. There were people working here for years that should have been cut far sooner, the kindness of management is really the only genuine criticism you could point to in that area

At times, this company could be seen more like a family; there's squabbles, rivalries and pettiness like there is anywhere, it's human nature. But everything is perspective, some adapt and some don't, these are life skills and often say more about the way people deal with things than anything else. 

The people who don't fit in here are usually the ones who want to make it into something it's not.  

A lot of the cons mentioned vary from department to department so some of them may be considered to be fair and valid. Areas that are continuously being improved include: On Board Training, Processes, Progression opportunities, Incentives, Recognition along with all the incredible perks that come with working here

Like any place you work, you have to earn your stripes and some people seem to lose patience after a few weeks or a month or two if it doesn't happen for them that quickly. Hard work is rewarded if people listen to the advice given to them and learn from it, some people would rather just blame others for their lack of ability to deliver, than acknowledge their own shortcomings  

Please don't think my own experiences here haven't been tested. I have had huge issues with staff and management at times, but we've worked through them and grown all the better for it both as people and professionals.  This is because they are human beings that try to understand your perspective and if you extend them the same courtesy, it tends to end productively and with reasonable solutions and lessons learnt. 

It's a company, a company which has grown very quickly and tried to incorporate many different perspectives into the mix, sometimes this means you'll have to fight to have your perspective listened to, but if you do it with a little common sense and patience, management will give you respect and talk to you like an adult (This has not been common in most places I've worked)

The transparency here does tend to fluctuate, knowing where to draw the line these days with this is difficult to handle. But things are continuously being improved, If they weren't, I wouldn't be here. 

All I can tell you is I have worked in a lot of autocratic style call centres with very toxic environments, If I got the slightest inclination I was working somewhere which was becoming like that? I would be the first one out the door, trust me

Some people have obviously had very sheltered lives and expect companies to be completely perfect. Not sure where they've worked before, but if they think this place is bad? I can't see the future being particularly bright for them

It's human nature to complain, there's always stuff to bicker about, but once again, to summarise, my worst day here, is better than any other place I've worked. If people are getting that angry, the majority of it will be self inflicted 

As for the drug culture, whilst I could be objective and acknowledge it is a very relaxed company, I've never seen anything obtrusive, overt, offensive or disrespectful to others. Whilst some complaints may be fair and legitimate, I'd say a lot of them are opportunistic and once again coming from a place of bitterness and intolerance.
